text: Zeke vanderhook principal of the equity
project Charter
School it was a phenomenal experience I
think that during the first year the
learning curve was like most first year
teachers
tremendous um and I got what I wanted
which was to be thrown in um and to sort
of thrive
or not Thrive based on my own abilities
um so I got the challenge that I was
looking for um Teach for America itself
you know has evolved a great deal since
I was a core member um and I think
they're a phenomenal organization so U
but you know my experience was really an
experience of just a first year teacher
in New York City hired by the city
essentially teach from America placed me
um and offered some support
But ultimately it was me and 32 sixth
graders I was a teacher in a school that
was pretty chaotic um so for me it was
actually great because I got to close my
classroom door nobody knew what I was
doing um and I got to be creative and
experiment um and also find what worked
for me I had a phenomenal Mentor um who
would sit in the back of the room once a
week um and then debrief with me and he
must have saved me from Reinventing the
wheel um so that was a really positive
takeaway you know in terms of the school
environment itself what I took away was
that there are pockets of greatness in a
lot of schools there were colleagues of
mine who were phenomenal but to a large
extent they are the exception not the
rule in an underresourced urban School
my own experience um at the middle
school the public middle school that I
taught in was that there were core
members like myself who were placed in
the school and there were other teachers
who had nothing to do with Teach for
America and we got along very well um
there was little sort of oh you were
placed through this program or you
weren't U there were a lot of Veteran
teachers I mentioned the mentor um who
was a retired veteran teacher who was
just a phenomenal influence on me and my
teaching style um so you know I think uh
in general Teach for America is a a
wonderful organization because it gets
people into teaching who might not
otherwise consider it um and if you look
at a lot of the Teach for America alumni
a lot of us uh um remain in education um
many in the classroom many starting
schools uh um and many at uh a more
senior level in uh in administration or
in at the district
level I think a teacher that responded
to me as an
individual um took an interest in me and
my own sort of ideas or my own
personality and went beyond just sort of
what was in the book that's one element
and the other element was really I
remember my history teacher in 9th grade
and 11th grade she really made you see
the world in a different way so a great
teacher in that sense was somebody who
really challenged his or her students to
get out from their their their own world
from their own perspective and see
things that they never thought of before
ways of seeing the
world the idea is completely
unoriginal um the idea that teachers are
the central lever in educ education is
sort of obvious the idea that we have to
respect them and we can't respect them
simply by paying lip service to
respecting them is also completely
unoriginal many many people have said
the country and the education system
will not improve until teachers are paid
a decent wage um so the idea is sort of
common sense it didn't come to me in a
Flash I think it's out there in the
culture the only sort of challenge was
how to implement it uh um so when I was
in the classroom teaching sixth grade
for a couple years and then 8th grade um
one of the things that really appealed
to me was the whole idea of public
charter schools because public charter
schools essentially
free um teachers and free an
Administration from the constraints of a
large bureaucracy and allow creative
individuals to to create a school that
they think will produce better results
and produce better more educated kids
than a traditional school so it's a very
entrepreneurial venture the idea of a
public charter school it really gives
people who think they know what they're
doing and maybe we don't but the
opportunity to at least um see if we can
create a school um that is outstanding
freed from the constraints of a large
bureaucracy and the flip side of course
that appealed to me is charter schools
at least in theory are really supposed
to be held accountable in a way that
public that traditional public schools
are not public charter schools really
have to meet certain goals U um in order
for their Charter to be renewed and
that's also very appealing because you
can actually see whether you've been
successful or not in New York state um
if you're writing a charter you
typically get uh a document from the
state that says here are the goals that
you have to put in your Charter there's
not much Choice um the goals Center a
lot around attendance standardized test
results uh um parent teacher student
satisfaction and I think all those are
important though I will say this I think
the emphasis on standardized tests uh
represents a relatively low bar um if
kids are not passing the New York State
English language arts exam then
certainly the school is doing something
wrong however if they are passing that
exam I don't necessarily think that
means the school is a great school there
are a lot of other factors that go into
whether the students are learning and
whether the school is excellent just to
give one example um standardized exams
have a very difficult time assessing
whether a student can write um which in
my view is one of the most important if
not the most important skill that
emerges after 12 years of schooling um
um you much more easily can measure that
through something like a writing
portfolio where you to get a sample of a
kid's writing every two weeks in
different disciplines and sort of see
over the course of the year what was the
student writing in September and what
was the student writing in June and
assessing that for content for form for
grammar all of that to me is a much more
robust measure of whether the school is
being successful and the students are
being successful than a standardized
test which are important in my view but
represent a relatively low bar one of
the things that we that we're trying to
do is is really have the teachers get a
lot out of the school environment as
well obviously that's a focus of the
school the idea that a school is not
just for students um it's also a place
where adults work um and I think if you
have a school that buys into the
mythology that teachers are sort of
sacrificial Lambs who should do
everything in service um of the children
and and should negate themselves
ultimately you hurt the kids um and
ultimately you hurt the school
environment so we're trying to create a
school environment where teachers
themselves are viewed as Learners and
their own growth as Learners and as
people uh um is developed one of the
ways we do this is we have an annual
summer development Institute for six
weeks uh uh where there are no kids
teachers spend that time reflecting on
their own practice another example is
that every five years or so the teachers
are required to leave the school for a
year and take a sabatical a mandatory
sabatical what do they do during that
year there's no requirement they don't
even have to connect it in fact we don't
want them to connect it to what they're
doing in the classroom and how it's
going to make them a better teacher we
want them to go skiing for a year if
that's what they want to go get an art
history Masters if that's what they've
always wanted to do um get a job um
another job so really we're valuing
their own growth as people and they're
allowed to have interests outside of
teaching I'm not a
historian but I know that a lot of the
devaluation of the teaching profession
has to do with the fact that you know
not so long ago it was really a
profession that was only open to women
for example um and so culturally um the
status of the profession uh um was not
uh what it should be um as the workforce
opened up uh to women I think what
happened is teaching became uh instead
of something that very talented women
who couldn't get other jobs because of
the constraints and the culture got um
now it was open to anybody uh um and it
didn't pay very well and that Talent so
to a certain extent drained from the
profession potentially this is just a
theory I really have no idea uh um and
what you're left with is pockets of
greatness so you have great teachers
throughout the country phenomenal
teachers but ultimately they're the
exception not the rule uh um and that's
because we don't culturally value
teachers uh um people make the mistake
of thinking that the salary that we're
offering U is somehow designed to make a
mediocre teacher better completely wrong
if you pay somebody more it's not going
to make them a better teacher that's
completely missing the point of the
project the point of the project is to
change the perception uh of who should
become a teacher uh um it's to change
the sort of lip service mode of oh
teachers we really value you to
something conrete in this culture money
is a signifier of value um and so
ultimately the goal is to attract more
Talent into into the profession right
now we draw from the bottom third of
college graduates to make up our
teaching force uh um and that's you know
that's unfortunate uh the goal should be
to draw from the top third of college
graduates to to make up our teaching
Force I think actually teaching um is
one of those professions where there
many people who secretly want to do it
and enjoy it when they're up there but
don't really view it as feasible they
can't support a family uh um it's not
really um realistic um to to achieve
other goals that they may have so I
think teaching has a built-in advantage
over some other professions uh um where
for and I'm not not to pick on lawyers
but you know I think there are a lot of
people who love the law but there are a
lot of people who go into the law just
because it is it pays the bills um and
it's a relatively uh lucrative and
respected profession um in that sense I
think teaching actually has a great
advantage over other professions the the
problem is that right now it's not
realistic for a lot of people who are
talented to go into it or they don't
view it as realistic
and you know one of the interesting
things about Teach for America is a lot
of people um who start the program think
oh I'll just do this for a few years but
then they fall completely madly in love
with it and stay on for the rest of
their career so that I think is less
likely to happen in some other
professions but teaching has a certain
magic to it that really gives it a lot
of
advantages we
hired who we think are eight grade
teachers um we'll find out um but they
have a very extensive track record for
the most part um several of the teachers
have over 30 years of
experience um the teacher you know the
youngest teacher we hired still has
seven years of experience in the
classroom so one thing is we're not
hiring sort of firste teachers because
uh um not that first year teachers can't
be great but um but the learning curve
is you know is is tremendous in that
first year so we're hiring veteran
teachers we're hiring teachers who you
know we actually visited their
classrooms everybody who made the final
round we went and saw them and so we're
hiring teachers who uh um in their
classroom developed a certain
relationship that was apparent to an
outsider with their students uh um
teachers who are thoughtful
practitioners who are reflective about
what they do in the classroom who can
talk about what they do in the classroom
in an in a reflective way uh um in a
critical way uh um they can they really
think about all of the decisions that
they make we're talking about teachers
who show that they could really engage
students capture that enthusiasm which
is particularly important I think for
middle school kids um and also teachers
who are adapt at creating structures for
kids uh uh middle school kids again in
particular need structure um and they
need um a teacher who can manage a class
um through routines through a variety of
of modalities but those were some of the
things that we looked for plus of course
we were looking for teachers who were
passionate about their subject uh um and
who could bring that passion and that
extensive knowledge to their students I
actually don't think so I would make the
case that one of the things about the
school that's very important is we do
this on the public dollar we are a
public charter school in New York City
we actually get less money than a
traditional Public School in New York
City
and yet we are able to pay teachers
$125,000 a year plus a potential bonus
based on schoolwide performance without
fundraising for that salary the only
thing we fundraise for is our facility
and that's because we don't get a free
public facility like every other school
gets but every other cost is absorbed or
is paid for by our public dollars that
we receive we have simply reallocated
those dollars and said you know what
really we need to be investing in the
most important part of the educational
experience for students and that's their
teachers we need to invest in what we
call teacher Equity hence the name the
equity project uh um and yes we are
going to sacrifice some other things to
do so we're not going to have tiny
classes um we have 30 kids in a class um
that's not higher than I I experienced
as a teacher in fact it's a little bit
lower but it's certainly not small um we
are going to do without a lot of the
other Personnel in the building that
typically would be in a school um so
we're going to do a lot of things to
make sacrifices in order to be able to
invest in what we think is more coste
effective in the long run which is
investing in the
teachers it varies from state to state
so I only really know how to start a
charter school in New York and that's
essentially their three authorizing
agencies in New York the New York City
Department of Education Sunni um which
is the State University of New York and
the Board of Regents um you decide who
you want to apply to and then you go
through their application process you
need a board um because charter schools
are public schools that are nonprofits
they're set up as nonprofits uh um and
you go through the process when we did
it first we had to write a concept paper
um the we applied through the New York
City Department of Education they
narrowed down all the concept papers
they received then we went in for an
interview then we wrote a more extensive
application so there are various stages
along the way and ultimately it's a
pretty long process I think it took us
close to a year from when we started the
process or at least when I started
writing the charter to when we actually
got approved uh and and a charter is
essentially a contract it's a five-year
contract so we have a five-year contract
with New York state that says hey we are
a public school we receive public money
just like the public school down the
street the difference is that we can
sort of run how we want want to run
within certain parameters we operate the
way we want to operate a good example is
we can pay teachers what we want to pay
them um and then at the end of the five
years we are evaluated based on whether
we've met the results the goals that are
laid out in our Charter if we have we're
offered a renewal for 5 years if not
then we're shut
down it depends on the public system New
York City happens to have schools that
aren't public that aren't Charter
Schools but are autonomy schools or
empowered schools so the flexibility may
or may not be quite as high as what a
charter school administrator and staff
can can make um but um there certainly
are schools certainly are much more
flexible uh um and principles are much
more empowered now in New York City
Public Schools than they were say 10
years ago um so again degrees of
flexibility vary but I think um a lot of
the things that might at one time have
not been the purview of a school a
principle now
are I mean I guess the two things that
come to mind initially is I would invest
a lot more in teachers and I would
incentivize schools to do so um with the
ultimate goal of expanding the talent
pool and the second and obviously I'm
biased because I'm running a charter
school is
I think um charter schools are
phenomenal vehicles for Innovation and
right now there is sort of inequity in
funding for Charter Schools charter
schools which are public schools get
less money than traditional public
schools in particular they don't get
facilities which is a huge barrier to
growth um so those are the two things
that I would do um to you know if I
somehow somebody somehow put a crown on
my head and said you can you can go do
whatever you want in education
you know I think Charter Schools work
and in large measure the reason that
they work is that when they don't work
they're allowed to be closed um so I
think one of the great things about the
charter school model is there is a
mechanism
for evaluating schools the schools that
are great continue the schools that are
not should be shut down it's very hard
to do that in in the traditional public
system there's no real mechanism for
shutting down a traditional Public
School in a way that makes a lot of
sense um sure they they're sort of
restructurings of schools but that's
very different than shutting it down so
I think one of the reasons Charter
Schools work is not that they're all
successful but that there's a mechanism
for evaluating whether the school is
successful um you know there are
phenomenal charter schools out there uh
um there are a lot of Charter management
organizations that uh um have had great
results um Kip Achievement First
uncommon schools are three that come to
mind um there are a lot of mom and pop
charter schools out there that have been
very very successful um you know I don't
know because I I don't really believe
anything I read until I walk into a
school um so I'm not the best person to
say oh this is the best charter school
or this is the best charter school
management organization but clearly
there are a lot of charter schools that
are doing things that are right
I think sanitized tests have their place
uh um I am sort of a moderate on this
point I think that one of the good
things that they do is they can really
help pinpoint when a school is really
not being successful um a standardized
test that tests basic reading where half
the kids in the school fail that's a
huge problem and it exposes that problem
and I think that's a very important part
of a standardized test the flip side is
a standardized test is not why we go to
school uh um and you know it's limited
in its uses um schools are places that
should be about much more than bubbling
in answers to a series of questions um
and I think any great school that you
walk into doesn't have the feel of a
standardized test exam Factory um and we
all know what that feels like the feel
of a great classroom the feel of
excitement in the classroom so you know
on the issue of standardized tests again
I think that they can expose problems
better than they can sort of show
greatness I think one of the challenges
is we need one of the challenges is that
we need to find other mechanisms for
schools to show their success um
standardized tests has been sort of is
the dominant mechanism right now I don't
think that's go going to go away until
we sort of as a culture
uh um Embrace other means um the writing
portfolio is a good example uh um every
subject has its own sort of other ways
of demonstrating success if you're in
music can you play a musical instrument
can you perform in a concert can you
sing can you site read uh U so there
every every discipline has its own ways
of demonstrating Mastery uh um and I
think the challenge is not to say oh we
should get rid of all standardized tests
but really to complement standardized
test with other uh more creative and
more meaningful ways to assess whether
students are
learning well I don't view uh the role
of principal as purely administrative I
also view it as the role of permanent
substitute so I actually get to teach in
all classrooms uh um and I don't think
I'd be happy if it was simply an
administrative role my hope is to be in
classrooms a lot um helping teachers um
providing feedback teaching myself so
I'm not I'm not that um daunted by the
fact that oh now I'm going into
administrative role because I don't
really view it completely in that
way every we've been very careful about
planning a teacher's day so that it's
not overwhelming so that it's actually
more sustainable than what I experienced
when I was teaching sixth grade and
teaching four subjects and doing an
after school activity Etc so we've done
a few things one every teacher at the
school only teaches one subject to one
grade so they really only have to
prepare one thing if I'm the fifth grade
math teacher I teach fifth grade math to
four different groups of kids but I only
have to prepare that one subject in
terms of taking on an outside role uh um
every teacher takes on One and Only One
role that would normally be filled by um
an administrator an example is one
teacher on each grade level would be the
director of assessment uh um another
example one teacher on each grade level
would be the director of parent
involvement and
attendance um and so one of the ideas
behind this is not only that of course
we're eliminating a bunch of
Administrators who cost money um but
also that it makes more sense for kids
especially kids who are struggling to
have fewer points of contact if a kid is
struggling and there's a
parent coordinator there is an assistant
principal there's a Dean there's the
principal there's a social worker
there's a guidance counselor there are
all the students teachers it's very hard
to solve that problem um whereas if you
sort of limit it to maybe the students
teachers a social worker and the
principal uh um there's more effective
communication in general and there're
more pieces that are fit together as
opposed to everybody having a tiny
little piece which makes it very
challenging to solve whatever the issue
is
